message: In a hint of what's to come, the first act of Trump's Congress is to gut ethics law, make corruption easier to hide.
Happy swearing in day to all the new members of the 115th Congress! Four years ago at my swearing in my son Rider decided he wanted to take the oath of office too.

Thanks to the Affordable Care Act, 20 million Americans now have health insurance. Sick people can't be kicked off their plans. People are no longer being bankrupted by medical bills. We can fix the Affordable Care Act together - or Republicans can repeal it without a replacement plan and harm millions of Americans.

I can’t stand the idea of a brave soldier risking her or his life for this country, suffering the wounds of battle, and then being kicked to the curb as a result of those very same wounds. But that is exactly what has happened to tens of thousands of men & women who fought in the Middle East and Vietnam. I've worked hard on this issue under President Obama and I'll continue to push President-Elect Trump to make sure that our men & women who serve get the care they need when they return home.

Today I introduced an amendment with U.S. Senator Tim Kaine opposing Republican efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act without a replacement. I wanted to take a minute to tell you a little more about it.

In Massachusetts and other states across the country, people with mental illness often wait for hours, sometimes days, in the ER. We passed the Mental Health Reform Act last month specifically to target this problem and I'm hopeful that I will help get people out of the ER and into the care they need.

The Republican plans to defund Planned Parenthood means taking care away from 2.5 million women and families who rely on them every year. I will not step aside as the GOP attempts to strip healthcare from millions of Americans. I will fight this tooth and nail. #IStandwithPP

The vast majority of Americans don't want Congress to repeal the ACA without a replacement - yet that is exactly what Republicans are trying to do. Right now, they are barreling forward to repeal the law, without showing the American people their plan to replace it.

I was proud to join my colleagues in holding the Senate floor late into the night to tell real stories of Connecticut families who depend on the Affordable Care Act. Republicans this week are taking the first step to repealing this lifesaving law -- but they won't show Americans what their plan is for the 30 million people who stand to lose coverage.

Repealing the Affordable Care Act with no immediate replacement will take insurance and medicines away from those who can't afford them otherwise. It can sound like hyperbole, but it's not. I know people back home in Connecticut who will lose insurance & medication without the ACA. They will die without it.   Some of my Republican colleagues understand the terrible consequences of ripping up the health care system without an immediate fix. I hope Congressional leaders will listen to them. Our constituents sent us here to fight for them -- it's times like this that matter most.

Repealing the Affordable Care Act without an *immediate* replacement would throw the health care market into chaos and cause 30 million Americans to lose their health insurance. We can't let that happen.

Today I joined hundreds at the State Capitol to rally and speak out against Congressional Republicans’ effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act and take away health coverage from millions of Americans. Jon from Meriden suffers from cystic fibrosis. He said, “Without the Affordable Care Act, I’d be dead.”  Make no mistake, the Affordable Care Act isn’t perfect. And I want to work with Republicans make it better. But to flat out repeal it with absolutely no solution for the over 20 million Americans who will lose access to health insurance—and even more who will now have to worry about lifetime caps or pre-existing conditions and whether their adult children can stay on their health insurance—is unconscionable.

Today, we recognize the life and legacy of one of my personal heroes, Martin Luther King Jr. There are many forces that seek to divide us, but we must worth together as a nation to rise above that. There is much work left to be done. I hope today pushes us all to work harder to make Dr. King’s dream a reality.
Refugee kids playing violin at the Music Haven concert. Are these the ones that threaten America, GOP?

Last night, Donald Trump's nominee to be Secretary of Education would not oppose putting guns in our schools. I was shaken to the core by her answer. Every American parent should've been too.   It's not enough to think school shootings are sad -- of course, we all think that. What I want to know is how the incoming administration plans to keep guns away from dangerous  people.
Yesterday I talked with CNN's Erin Burnett about why Trump nominees like Betsy DeVos should send shivers down the spine of every parent in this country.

Over the last eight years, President Barack Obama oversaw the longest streak of job creation in our nation's history. He helped 20 million people gain access to health insurance and protected all of us from being denied coverage simply because of a preexisting condition. He openly supported the right of same-sex couples to marry, and he protected millions of Dreamers from deportation. He inspired a generation of young people to believe in the power of public service, and he encouraged all of us to believe in the power of hope. It was not always easy, but President Obama represented to so many of us what America can and should be. Connecticut will miss him. And so will I. Thank you, Mr. President.

Today, I congratulate President Trump on his inauguration and I give thanks to President Obama for his extraordinary presidency.   I know how you're feeling. This isn't the inauguration any of us hoped for. And like you, I am worried about the future of our country.  But I know that my fear is nothing compared to the fear many families across the country are feeling right now. I am not going to lose my health care. No one is trying to deport the Murphys of Connecticut. And as a white man from the northeast, there is no systematic effort to deny my reproductive or voting rights.  But here's my promise to you: I am going to fight for those families every single day. Because that's our choice right now; we can give into our despair, or we can fight.   I choose to fight.  Like many of you, I am not entirely sure what the next days, weeks, months and years will hold. But I do know that the only way forward is if we stand together.   Today, I truly wish Trump well, because his fate is now tied to the fate of our nation. I will work with him if he changes course and chooses a path that brings the country together. But if he pursues the divisive, hurtful policies that he made a hallmark of his campaign, I'll fight him with every ounce of my being.   Nothing is inevitable. Nothing is impossible. Take the anxiety, fear, and sadness you feel today and turn it into political action.
Wrapping up dinner for friends marching tomorrow. My 8-year-old needed help coloring his poster for Mom to carry.
What is happening today is extraordinary. And it's not going away. #WomensMarch

My wife Cathy and her friends were ready to march today! (I stayed home to watch all the kids). This movement is big - millions across the country and tens of thousands in Connecticut alone. 10,000 in Hartford, 5,000 in Stamford and even 500 in tiny Salisbury, CT!
I will vote no on Rex Tillerson in Foreign Relations Committee today. His record of putting profits before country at Exxon is disqualifying.

Since I was first elected to Congress in 2006, I've pushed the government to Buy American when it comes to spending taxpayer dollars. I started the Buy American caucus when I was in the House and I've introduced two bills - the 21st Century Buy American Act & the American Jobs Matter Act - to help support American manufacturing and jobs.  Donald Trump has said over and over that his administration will follow two principles - Buy American and Hire American. If he's serious about keeping that promise, I have a few ideas for him. Today, I proposed five executive actions he can take today to make that happen.

Throughout the entire campaign, Trump's team insisted he wasn't releasing his tax returns because he was under audit. Over the weekend, his senior advisor suggested that's not the case. He never intended to release his returns, denying the American people vital information about who he's in debt to, where his investments are or how he might personally benefit from the policies he enacts as president of the United States. I worked to introduce a bill requiring President Trump and all future candidates to release their tax returns. It's more important than ever that Congress pass it.
Why is it that so many of Trump's cabinet appointees think the rules don't apply to them?

President Trump said over and over again on the campaign trail that he wants to rebuild our roads and bridges and invest in infrastructure and create American jobs. If he actually wants to deliver on that promise, here's his chance.

My number one priority as U.S. Senator is keeping the people of Connecticut safe. But President Trump's dangerous and divisive actions today do nothing to make us safer. Building walls and taking money away from local police does not make us safer.   Our greatness as a country is rooted in our immigrant history. Anyone who tries to turn our country against immigrants is preying on prejudice.   I've worked with Republicans and Democrats to find solutions to fix our broken immigration system - solutions that will to secure our border, deport criminals, keep families together and let people who have worked hard and paid their taxes find a path to citizenship. I'm going to keep working to make those policies a reality. But I won't stand for misguided policies that are rooted in bigotry and fear. I will fight the President on these actions tooth and nail.

I will vote NO on Betsy DeVos for Secretary of Education.  Education has always been personal to me - my mom was a teacher, both of my young sons are in public school, and my wife, a former teacher, has spent her career advocating for low-income students. Every child in this country deserves to have access to a quality education - no matter where they live, the color of their skin, how they learn, or how much money their family has.   After meeting with Betsy DeVos one-on-one and listening to her responses in the committee hearing, I cannot support her nomination to be the next Secretary of Education. Mrs. DeVos said she supports the rollback of gun-free zones in schools, making students less safe. Her answer to my question about guns in schools, which went viral on the internet, was deeply troubling. And when asked about federal laws protecting students with disabilities, she failed to say she'd enforce them, which is beyond frightening for kids with disabilities and their families. The only thing more frightening is that her shaky answer on protecting kids with disabilities may have been caused by the fact that she didn't actually know we have a federal law protecting these kids.   But most importantly, I've heard from thousands and thousands of my constituents that they do not want Mrs. DeVos and the policies she is proposing anywhere near their children's schools. She has called public schools a "dead end" for kids. Sure, public schools need to get better, but we cannot have a Secretary of Education who will make it her mission to empty out our public schools and hand the reins of our kids' education over to Wall Street and for-profit school operators. I will oppose her nomination.
The new federal hiring freeze imposed by President Trump will mean fewer jobs and services for our veterans.

America is a nation of immigrants. Just ask my great-grandparents, who immigrated to the U.S. from Poland, or the millions of people who came to our shores seeking a better life. We need immigration reform that keeps our country secure, while also keeping families together. We need reforms that use our resources to remove criminals, while creating a path to citizenship for the 11 million people living in the shadows. President Trump's actions this week do nothing to get us closer to that goal - they only seek to divide us and reinforce the same bigoted and xenophobic rhetoric he used on the campaign trail.
This is the new normal if you try to trample people's rights. Just FYI.

The Muslim ban signed by President Trump today is a moral abomination that flies in the face of our founding principles. It's also likely to get Americans killed. I wrote a piece for Huffington Post explaining why the ban will make our country less safe. I hope you'll take a few minutes to read it.
To my colleagues: don't ever again lecture me on American moral leadership if you chose to be silent today.

Trump's crackdown on Muslim immigrants and refugees is a moral abomination that our forsakes our fundamental values and puts American lives at risk. This policy is not who we are as a nation. It’s not who we should be. I will fight it with all that I have.
The law is clear. The Muslim ban is illegal. I will introduce a bill this week to immediately overturn this dangerous, hateful order.

Yesterday I talked to Vox about the danger President Trump's Muslim ban poses to our national security and our moral foundation as a country. And why I hope my Republican colleagues will stand with me in fighting back against this policy.
This morning I talked with the team at Morning Joe about why Trump's "Muslim Ban" makes America less safe and my plan to introduce legislation to block it.

Today I introduced legislation to block President Trump's shameful executive order banning refugees from our shores. People across the country have spoken out against it. Congress needs to show the world that America is better than this.

This morning in committee I voted NO on Betsy DeVos's nomination to be our next Secretary of Education. During her hearing, Mrs. DeVos showed a disturbing lack of knowledge about basic education policy and laws. She didn't seem to know what was required of states when it comes to educating kids with disabilities. She made it clear that she viewed the enforcement of civil rights protections for our kids as optional. She was confused about the difference between measuring growth and proficiency. And instead of talking with me directly about the danger of guns in our classrooms, she said she would support a federal law barring gun free zones in schools because of the threat of grizzly bears.   In all my time in Congress, I've never seen people in Connecticut respond to a nominee like they did after that hearing - 11,000 people called and wrote my office to oppose her nomination. Thousands more tweeted and shared messages and comments here on Facebook. Almost no one called to support her. That's remarkable. I voted no on Mrs. DeVos's nomination today because our kids deserve better than this.
TODAY, January 31st, is the last day to sign up for health insurance. Make sure that you and your family are covered. Go to healthcare.gov and enroll today.
Trump's propensity for lies puts our country in a dangerous position and leaves our allies wondering whether they can still trust the United States.

Tune in to Hardball with Chris Matthews tonight for their special town hall on "Power & the Presidency." I'll be talking after Kellyanne Conway about Trump's first two weeks in office and discussing the refugee ban with Khizr Khan and others. Gonna be interesting. Watch live at 7:00 ET on MSNBC
I hope you'll take a few minutes to ready my latest piece in The Huffington Post on how Donald Trump's reckless actions over the first weeks of his presidency are bringing us closer to war with Iran.

Last night I joined Hardball with Chris Matthews for a town hall at American University. We talked about why silencing dissent is dangerous and why the President's reckless actions are endangering U.S. foreign policy. I hope you'll take a minute to watch
THIS is who we really are. The Kassar girls, 8 and 5, Syrian refugees, arrive in Milford tonight. "Welcome to America," I said.
This is welcome news. Trump's executive order is unconstitutional and he should rescind it immediately. We won't stop fighting until the ban is overturned.
Yesterday I met with teachers in New Haven. Here's what they had to say about Betsy DeVos.

Some good news at the end of a long week as the Kassar family was reunited yesterday. My staff worked tirelessly with the family and their lawyer to make sure Fadi could see his wife and two little girls again. Today, they're settling into their new home in Connecticut.

Was back home in Connecticut on Friday. I met with teachers and parents in New Haven who are concerned about Betsy DeVos, rode the bus in West Haven to hear from commuters about what they want me to be working on in Washington and, best of all, welcomed the Kassar family to their new home in Milford.
Took the 4am shift. The chances you will be watching are bested only by the chances a grizzly bear walks into your kid's school today.

Today, I voted against Betsy DeVos because people in Connecticut couldn't understand why a person who has fought so hard to undermine public schools would be put in charge of them. They told me this loud and clear - with a record number of calls, letters, emails, tweets and more. I heard from parents and teachers who were concerned about Mrs. DeVos’s agenda, and as a parent of two young boys, I share those concerns.  But today, The Senate voted to confirm her, with Vice President Pence breaking a 50-50 tie. Now that Mrs. DeVos is confirmed, I’m going to work to help her understand the value of our public schools. I'm going to make sure that she hears the concerns you shared with me. I’ll work overtime to help when she’s doing something that’s good for kids, and I promise that I will fight to stop her when she’s not.  To every person who called, emailed, tweeted, commented or showed up in person, I want to say thank you. If we've learned anything over the past few weeks it's that pushing back on those in power and demanding to be heard can make a difference. We cannot win every fight, but do not allow for setbacks to silence you. We came so close on this one, and victories will inevitably come our way if we keep speaking truth to power.   Do not doubt your power as a citizen. Keep holding us accountable. We need your action and your advocacy now more than ever.
Today I talked with CNN's New Day about Donald Trump's relationship with Vladimir Putin and what it means the for the United States. Take a minute to watch if you can.

I want to talk for a minute about what happened on the floor of the Senate last night. You probably already heard that Elizabeth Warren was silenced by Mitch McConnell when she attempted to read a letter from Coretta Scott King on the floor. And while this action is concerning on its face, I want to talk about what it means in the context of this political moment we're living in.  We have a President of the United States who is a bully. He is using the power of his office to try and stifle debate. If you oppose him, he will mock you and degrade your reputation in an effort to silence you. We've seen him do it to ordinary Americans, elected officials, and maybe most troublingly to independent members of our judiciary system. President Trump's treatment of a judge in Washington who ruled against his travel ban shows a total disregard for the founding principle of our democracy - the checks and balances of independent, co-equal branches of government. It's an exceptional moment when the President of the United States is trying to bully judges into ruling in his favor.  I'm not trying to equate what happened on the floor of the Senate last night with what our President has done, but I want us to be very aware of efforts to stifle debate and quell opposition to this President, his cabinet, and his agenda. And while it may be true that the rules of the Senate don't allow you to talk about the conduct of a fellow Senator, how on earth can you debate a Cabinet nominee who happens to be a member of the Senate without questioning their conduct?  The continued effort to try to stop people who oppose President Trump and his agenda from speaking truth to power is not right. We are not going to stop talking about Senator Sessions' record, we are not going to stop questioning actions we see as threatening to our national security, and we will not be silent.
I just left the floor of the Senate where I voted against the nomination of Jeff Sessions to serve as our nation’s next Attorney General.
I know Tom Price. And I know exactly what he wants to do to the American health care system. That's why I'm so strongly opposed to his nomination to be Secretary of Health & Human Services.
Another blow against Trump's unconstitutional travel ban as courts continue to block its implementation. Trump should rescind it immediately.

It's 2:45 in the morning and I just voted NO on Tom Price to be the next Secretary of Health and Human Services. Tom has dedicated his career to dismantling Medicare and Medicaid and destroying the Affordable Care Act. If his plans for our healthcare system become a reality millions will lose their health insurance, costs will skyrocket and patient protections will be decimated.  This issue isn't about which party is right or wrong - it's about life and death and the health of millions of people. Families in Connecticut are afraid that they will lose the care they depend on. They're afraid that their loved ones won't be able to see the doctor if they get sick. They're afraid that one trip to the hospital could mean a lifetime of debt. I'm going to do everything I can to make sure that doesn't happen.

There's no good way to explain this. Either Trump directed his National Security Advisor to undermine U.S. foreign policy and coordinate sanctions relief for Russia before he was even inaugurated, or Flynn went rogue and did it on his own.   Either he lied to Vice President Mike Pence about what happened, or the Vice President knowingly went on TV and lied to the American people. Any way you slice it, this is bad.   I'm glad the FBI will continue its investigation because these reports raise more red flags about this administration's intentions and integrity.
If you have 12 minutes this weekend, watch this. It's really important.

Unreal. 3 days in, DeVos aligns with congressional Republicans to roll back civil rights protections, confirming all our fears. In her hearing, she said, "I support accountability." But she didn't even wait a week to abandon accountability standards for disabled & minority kids.  Instead of fighting to preserve accountability rules, DeVos's letter to the states says they aren't required to follow them. "States rights" was the rallying cry for segregationists. Racism still exists.

Earlier this week I talked with Craig Melvin about Andy Puzder, Trump's nominee to lead the Department of Labor who has a history of violating our country's labor laws. Take a few minutes to watch if you can.

General Flynn was coordinating with the Russian government while he was a private citizen, and then he lied about it. He had to go, but it's clear that we don't know the extent of the Trump/Russia story. Right now, there are way more questions than answers on President Trump's relationship with Russia. It's time for Congress to convene a bipartisan commission to get to the bottom of this.
This is a scary moment. U.S. Special Operations Command General now compelled to speak out against the White House. Almost unprecedented.
This is your daily reminder that at the center of this strengthening hurricane are the tax returns. It's time for President Trump to release his taxes.

I've heard my Republican friends say countless times that if we want to prevent gun violence, we should focus on enforcing the existing laws. They say we should focus on mental illness. We hear these lines every time there is an act of gun violence in the news. But today we learned that they don't mean it.   Because today, the Senate voted to weaken our background checks system and get rid of a rule that seeks to keep weapons out of the hands of people with serious mental illness. The rule simply states that if you've been found mentally impaired to the point where you cannot work and are unable to manage your own financial affairs, then there should be a transparent, fair process for limiting your access to guns. Thanks to a vote in the Senate today, that provision will be wiped off the books.   90% of Americans, including the majority of gun owners, support a strong background checks system. They support keeping guns out of the hands of dangerous people. No matter what state you live in, if you go sit down with your constituents and you tell them that you voted to allow people who are seriously mentally ill to be able to buy guns, you're not going to get a lot of takers. This isn't the will of the people - this is a gift to the gun lobby with a giant bow on top.

Russia is acting like it has a permission slip to flex its military muscles and push back against longstanding boundaries. The unanswered question is, why? I talked with Morning Joe about what we can do about it.

There are few people more ill-suited to run the Department of Labor than Andy Puzder - a man who is known for frequently violating labor laws and openly mocking workers. Now that Puzder has withdrawn, the President should nominate someone who has spent their career fighting to help workers - not belittling them.
In case you missed it, President Trump signed his first law this week. Now, oil and gas companies no longer need to disclose payments to foreign governments.

Before the Affordable Care Act, the majority of plans had lifetime caps - meaning once you reached a certain dollar amount, that's it! You're done! The plan would no longer cover your services and families would be left on the hook for all of those healthcare costs.   Timmy Morrison was born just a few months after the Affordable Care Act was signed into law. Because he was born prematurely and with a genetic condition, he needed to stay in the NICU where he had multiple surgeries. Timmy would have run through his lifetime cap when he was just three months old. What do you do when your kid is in the NICU and all of a sudden you're on the hook for millions of dollars in medical bills?   Luckily, this is a question the Morrisons and thousands of other families never had to answer because of the Affordable Care Act. Because the law got rid of lifetime caps, it meant they could focus on getting the best care possible for their kid and not have to fear that they would go bankrupt because of medical bills.   Timmy is six years old now. As Republicans talk about repealing the Affordable Care Act, his family is terrified that they will reinstate lifetime caps. As we get more into the debate around repealing the ACA, I want you to remember this family. These decisions about healthcare affect all of us -  but for people like Timmy, they are make or break.

Back on the graveyard shift this morning. I was up bright and early to talk about why Scott Pruitt would be a disaster for the EPA. For starters, Pruitt sued the very agency he now intends to lead--multiple times. He's poised to give oil and gas companies free rein to pollute, instead of taking action to fight climate change or protect our clean air and water. I'm voting NO on his confirmation today and I'll be working to hold him accountable.
Amidst all the stomach turning moments of yesterday's press conference, this is perhaps the hardest to watch.
I'm holding a town hall in West Hartford on Tuesday. I hope you'll come by and talk to me about the issues you care about and what you want me to be working on in Washington.

When it comes to President Trump's ties to Russia, the American people are left with more questions than answers. It's time for the President to release his tax returns and make it clear what investments he has in the country.
Must-read editorial from USA TODAY on the hypocrisy of Congress's latest move to make it easier for people with serious mental illness to get a gun.

Legalizing same-sex marriage in the U.S. not only helped couples finally marry under the law - it had other far-reaching benefits. Including reducing stigma and helping to bring down the suicide rate among LGB youth.

One of the big takeaways from my town hall last night - people are worried. About the environment, about this administration and what their policies are going to mean for families here in Connecticut. But they are also fired up. They're ready to take action and make their voices heard in a way I haven't seen in all my years of public service. This overwhelming response has lifted me up over this past month. I promise I'm going to keep fighting alongside you.
You know what takes courage? Learning to talk after being shot in the head. You know what takes no courage? Doing your job and facing your voters.

This debate is not just about bathrooms - it's about the message we are sending to transgender kids. About the places they can be themselves and whether they are deserving of safety and support. I'm deeply disappointed that the administration is pulling back on the protections in place for transgender students and I'm going to fight to ensure that these kids have the support they need.

Anyone who has ever sat in traffic on I-95 or tried to commute on Metro North knows that our transportation infrastructure in Connecticut is badly in need of repair. We've got a plan to think big when it comes to improving our roads and bridges and I'm hopeful that this is a place we can find common ground in Congress.

I met 8-year-old Francesca in New Haven this week and she asked me how I have the courage to stand up and try and make a difference when things get tough. And I told her, it's because I have an 8-year-old too. And when he grows up I want him to know that I did everything I could to fight for what I think is right. I want him to know I tried to help make the world safe, to keep our planet clean and to make sure he could be anything he wanted if he worked hard enough. I want that for my boys, for Francesca, and for every kid.

Earlier the week, a draft copy of the Republican plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act got out. Allow me to count the ways that this plan will totally, completely, monumentally screw you.  1. You get a couple thousand bucks to help you buy insurance. That's it. If you aren't rich or healthy, you won't be able to afford anything.  2. But, it gets worse. When you can't afford your premiums because the tax credit is too small and your coverage lapses, you get a huge penalty when you try to sign up again.  3. Coverage mandates and penalties only work if you make insurance affordable. The leaked GOP plan cuts subsidies so much that the penalty is unworkable.  4. Mandatory benefits are repealed. So even if you CAN get insurance, it doesn't have to cover ANYTHING. Out of pocket expenses skyrocket.  5. Oh, and Medicaid expansion is effectively GONE. Millions and millions lose coverage and start using emergency rooms again for health care. Others die.  6. Finally, If you're older, your premiums go WAY up because the Republican plan guts premium protections for older consumers.  The Affordable Care Act helped 20 million people get covered for the first time. It held insurance companies accountable for providing care for everyone. And it made sure that the most important services would always be covered, no matter what. I agree that we can improve the law to make it better, but this Republican plan for repeal would be a disaster for millions of Americans.

Students and families in Connecticut shouldn't have to live in fear. I sat down with Jewish Community Leaders in Woodbridge earlier this week to talk about this recent wave of threats and I'm going to work with communities in CT to help improve security. We need to stand together and fight back against the hateful rhetoric and anti-Semitism that's fueling these threats.

I hope you'll take a few minutes to ready my latest piece on The Huffington Post about why Trump's proposed "security budget" fails to address the pressing threats the U.S. faces today. Nothing about American misadventures in the Middle East since 2001 is an advertisement to solve our problems through military force alone.

I've been working to get the government to Buy American since I was first elected to Congress. And while we've made some serious progress, there's much more we can do. Closing these loopholes would help create thousands of jobs in Connecticut.
Version 2 of President Trump's travel ban still targets Muslims, still inspires more terrorism, still violates our founding principles. Oh, and it's still illegal.

President Trump's re-issued travel ban is just as much of a moral abomination as the first version halted by the courts several weeks ago. Closing our doors to those fleeing torture and terror is an abdication of our American values and it plays right into our enemies' hands. It is recruitment gold for ISIS and other terrorist organizations who are hoping to motivate lone-wolf attackers. Once again, I'm planning to introduce legislation to block it.

The new Republican health care bill is just a skeletal, slapdash, mean-spirited version of the ACA that would slash insurance coverage and spike costs.  Republicans decried individual mandate. Their bill has a mandate, it's just a crueler version that kicks in if you don't maintain continuous care. Then, it raises your costs through the roof.  Republicans decried tax credits. Their bill includes tax credits, but they are so skimpy that they help no one who isn't rich or healthy.  Republicans decried Medicaid expansion. Their bill keeps it, but only for 2 years, and only as a trade-off to gut the Medicaid program in 2020.  Bottom line - this Republican health care bill was jammed together in the dark. And it's a disaster. Millions will lose coverage and see huge cost spikes.
The world is freaked out because they see America's leadership vanishing before their eyes.

Colby Sue Weathers should never have been able to buy a gun. Her mom knew it. She called the local gun store, the ATF, and the FBI. It didn't matter. Colby was still able to purchase the firearm. Our weak gun laws did nothing to help prevent the tragedy that followed.
On International Women's Day and every day, I'm committed to the fight for equal opportunity for all women.
This is simple stuff. Trump promised to cover everyone.  He is now pushing a bill that ends insurance for millions.   Promise broken.

Last year, we passed my landmark bipartisan Mental Health Reform law to help make it easier for people struggling with mental illness and addiction to get the care they need. Our bill passed almost unanimously because every single Member of Congress knows someone touched by these issues. We cannot now turn our backs on those who need mental health care. I am going to do all that I can to protect the progress we've made.
Under Trumpcare, millions of Americans will lose their insurance, millionaires will get a giant tax cut and people in Connecticut, especially older people, will be left footing the bill.

A short primer on all the ways the Graham-Cassidy health care bill is an intellectual and moral garbage truck fire.  1. Graham-Cassidy eliminates protections for people who are or ever have been sick. GONE. Insurers are allowed to go back to denying coverage for the sick.  2. Lifetime caps, annual caps, charging older people more - all the greatest hits of Trumpcare are back and in this bill.  3. Medicaid expansion vanishes. Millions will lose insurance, including loads of people with disabilities and children.  4. Premiums go up for everyone by 20% in the first year alone. If you're over age 50 or low income it gets even worse for you after that.   5. Graham-Cassidy is also a massive funding cut to states. In the next decade, it cuts $4 billion in funding to Connecticut. In order to cope with the cuts, states will either slash programs or raise taxes.  Bottom line: Graham-Cassidy is a bill that was written in secret, hurts millions and makes every problem in the health care system worse, not better. It's time for us to mobilize and stop it in its tracks.

Today the House is voting on a national concealed weapons bill that would let anyone allowed to carry a concealed handgun in their own state – including individuals with criminal records from states that do not require background checks – to carry the weapon in any other state. Although many states, like Connecticut, require people seeking a permit to carry to pass a background check and undergo extensive gun-safety training, 12 states allow residents to carry concealed handguns without a permit or any training. Law enforcement hates this bill, and so do millions of Americans who believe we should have stronger gun laws. I'm urging my colleagues to dump this bill and work together to keep deadly weapons away from people we all already agree shouldn’t have them.

Tonight, advocates, community members and nearly 100 families who have lost a loved one gathered together for the 5th National Vigil for All Victims of Gun Violence. This event is always scheduled for early December, near the anniversary of the shooting at Sandy Hook. And coincidentally, these families were here today as the House voted on two gun provisions, which House leadership combined into a single bill. The first was our bipartisan Fix NICS Act, which would close loopholes in our background check system. The second was a concealed weapons provision that would allow people permitted to carry concealed weapons to carry them into any other state regardless of what that state’s law on such guns is. The first is supported by more than 90% of Americans. The other is opposed by law enforcement, ER doctors and the vast majority of Americans who believe that you should need to pass a background check or have some semblance of training to be able to carry a concealed firearm. But this has been the struggle of reforming our gun laws over the past five years. Thanks to the gun lobby, commonsense reforms are hard to pass, while unpopular NRA priorities are greenlighted by the Republican party.   But this is changing. Our movement is growing and it is strong. Politicians are realizing that they are out of step with their constituents. I believe this concealed carry bill will be dead on arrival in the Senate. And I'm hopeful that we can pass our bipartisan Fix NICS Act this year. The way we turn the tide is by showing up, sharing our stories and making our voices heard.   Tonight, I am grateful for the families from more than 20 states came to Washington to honor the people they lost to gun violence. I'm grateful for the advocates who have been relentless in their desire to make our country safer from gun violence. And I'm hopeful that we will succeed.

Five years ago, 26 lives were extinguished in a matter of moments at Sandy Hook Elementary School and thousands more were irrevocably altered - including mine. In the years since, Newtown has had to wrestle with the question of what kind of place it would be in the wake of this unimaginable tragedy. And while these years have seen their fair share of grief and mourning, they have also been marked by small miracles. And it's those miracles that I want us to reflect on today. 2017 was a year that sometimes left us feeling helpless. In the wake of natural disasters like Hurricanes Harvey and Maria and the wildfires in California. Following dark moments like the shootings in Las Vegas and Texas. In the face of rising tensions with adversaries like North Korea, or the worry that our loved ones might not have the health care they need.    But 2017 was also a year in which so many of us discovered our power. The power to speak out as a part of the #MeToo movement. The power to protest, to sit in, to show up and to vote. The power to face down something big and scary and make the decision to do something to help. Whether it was donating overwhelming amounts of aid to our neighbors in need, or organizing a group of friends to march for a cause, or simply resolving to be kinder to one another in our daily lives.   The lesson of 2017 is that there is plenty the exists outside of our control. But we have the power to build the world we want to live in. And we can do it together.   I want to thank you for giving me the chance to serve Connecticut this year and for letting me do my part to help solve the problems that we face. It's the honor of my life to do this job and I hope that you will keep fighting alongside me in 2018.

In 2017, I helped lead the charge against policies like the travel ban and the Republican health care bill. I kept fighting for common sense gun policies. And I spoke out against the President's reckless foreign policy behavior. I know that people in Connecticut want someone who is going to stand up for them in the Senate, even if it makes me vulnerable in my re-election next year. There are people with power and money who would be very happy to see me lose my seat in 2018. But we have something they don't - strong grassroots support. My campaign is powered by lots of people giving what they can. As we close the books on the final fundraising quarter for this year, I have to ask - will you consider chipping in $3 to help me win next year?
